after_election = | after_party = }} [[File:Blank Rus Election 2018.jpg|thumb|200px|An election ballot listing the presidential candidates]] The '''2018 Russian presidential election''' will take place on 18 March 2018.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rbc.ru/rbcfreenews/5a32b5ee9a7947c618036fa1?from=newsfeed|title=Совет Федерации назначил выборы президента на 18 марта|website=РБК|access-date=2017-12-15}} The first round will be held on Sunday 18 March 2018. If in the first round no candidate attains an absolute majority of the votes (more than half), then according to the law, a second round will take place exactly three weeks later, on 8 April 2018.{{cite web|url=http://cikrf.ru/law/federal_law/zakon_19.html|title=Федеральный закон от 10 января 2003 года № 19-ФЗ «О выборах Президента Российской Федерации» (ред. от 19.07.2009) - Центральная избирательная комиссия Российской Федерации|website=cikrf.ru|accessdate=24 June 2017}} On 6 December 2017, incumbent [[President of Russia|President]] [[Vladimir Putin]] announced that he would seek reelection for a second consecutive term{{Cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/russia-putin-hints-president-reelection-doesnt-announce/28900426.html|title=Putin Announces He Will Run For Reelection In March|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|access-date=2017-12-25}} and fourth term overall. Putin is widely expected to win, and has consistently scored higher than 40%, and often much higher, in [[Opinion polling for the Russian presidential election, 2018|opinion polls]] since the [[Russian presidential election, 2012|last presidential election]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-06/it-s-official-putin-seeks-to-extend-his-rule-until-2024|title=It's Official: Putin Says He'll Run for Re-Election|date=2017-12-06|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-12-07}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/dec/06/vladimir-putin-russian-president-running-re-election-march|title=Vladimir Putin makes it official – he's running for re-election in 2018|last=Walker|first=Shaun|date=2017-12-06|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-12-07|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} ==Background== [[File:President el in Russia 2018.png|thumb|250px|left|Election logo]] The [[President of Russia]] is [[Direct election|directly elected]] for a term of six years, since being extended from four years in 2008 during [[Dmitry Medvedev]]’s administration.Stefanov, Mike (22 December 2008). [http://www.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/12/30/russia.presidential.term.extension/ Russian presidential term extended to 6 years]. [[CNN]]. Retrieved 1 May 2017. As written in Article 81 of the [[Constitution of the Russian Federation]], a candidate for president must be at least 35 years old and has to have permanently resided in Russia for the past 10 years, and cannot serve more than two terms consecutively.[http://www.constitution.ru/en/10003000-05.htm Chapter 4. The President of the Russian Federation]. Constitution of the Russian Federation. Parties with representation in the [[State Duma]] are able to nominate a candidate to run for the office while candidates from officially registered parties that are not in parliament have to collect at least 100,000 signatures. [[Independent politician|Independent]] candidates have to collect at least 300,000 signatures with no more than 7,500 from each [[federal subject of Russia]][https://sputniknews.com/society/20120502173168974/ Medvedev Signs Off on Election, Party Signature Laws]. Sputnik News. Published 5 February 2012. Retrieved 1 May 2017. and also from action groups made up of at least 500 people.{{Cite news|url=https://meduza.io/news/2017/12/15/sovet-federatsii-ob-yavil-nachalo-kampanii-po-vyboram-prezidenta-rossii|title=Совет Федерации объявил начало кампании по выборам президента России|work=Meduza|access-date=2017-12-15|language=ru-RU}} The nomination process took place during [[Public holidays in Russia#New Year holiday|Russia’s winter holiday period]], and 31 January 2018 was the last day for submitting signatures in support of contested access candidates. ===Change of date=== On 3 March 2017, Senators Andrey Klishas and Anatoly Shirokov submitted to the [[State Duma]] draft amendments to the electoral legislation. One of the amendments involves the transfer of elections from the second to the third Sunday in March, i.e. from 11 to 18 March 2018.{{cite news |url=https://ria.ru/politics/20170307/1489462958.html |title=Поправки в законы о выборах могут принять к июню, считает Клишас |language=ru |publisher=[[RIA Novosti]] |date=2017-03-07}} According to article 5, paragraph 7 of Russian Federal law No. 19-FZ, "If the Sunday on which presidential elections are to be held coincides with the day preceding a public holiday, or this Sunday falls on week including a public holiday or this Sunday in is declared to be a working day, elections are appointed on the following Sunday". The second week of March includes [[International Women's Day]] (8 March), which is an official holiday in Russia.{{cite web|url=http://www.kremlin.ru/acts/bank/19006|title=Федеральный закон от 10.01.2003 г. № 19-ФЗ|publisher=[[Kremlin.ru]]|access-date=2018-01-10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170508124842/http://www.kremlin.ru/acts/bank/19006|archivedate=2017-05-08|language=ru}} The bill passed through the State Duma and [[Federation Council (Russia)|Federation Council]] without delay in May 2017 and was signed into law by Vladimir Putin on 1 June 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/a/russia-2018-presidential-vote-moved-crimea-anniversary/28427322.html|title=Russia To Move 2018 Presidential Vote To Day Marking Seizure Of Crimea|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|access-date=2017-04-27}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.kremlin.ru/events/president/news/54655|title=Внесены изменения в закон о выборах Президента Российской Федерации|work=Президент России|access-date=2017-06-01|language=ru}} On 15 December, the upper house of the [[Federal Assembly (Russia)|Federal Assembly]], the Federation Council, officially confirmed that 18 March 2018 will be the date of the election, officially beginning the process of campaigning and registration for candidates.[https://www.rt.com/politics/413295-upper-house-officially-sets-date/ Russian presidential election date set as March 18]. RT. Published 15 December 2017. Retrieved 16 December 2017. This date is significant as it is the fourth anniversary of [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Crimea re-joining Russia]] (in the vast majority of countries this is referred to as the Russian annexation of Crimea).[http://the-japan-news.com/news/article/0004135437 Campaign officially starts for Russia's presidential election]. [[The Japan News]]. Published 19 December 2017. Retrieved 19 December 2017. ===Nomination of candidates=== ====Free access==== Political parties represented in the [[State Duma]] and/or the legislative bodies of not less than one-third of the [[Federal subjects of Russia|federal subjects]] could nominate a candidate without collecting signatures. The following parties could nominate candidates without collecting signatures: [[Civic Platform (Russia)|Civic Platform]], the [[Communist Party of the Russian Federation]], the [[Liberal Democratic Party of Russia]], [[A Just Russia]], [[Rodina (political party)|Rodina]] and [[United Russia]]. On 1 July 2017, Chairman of Rodina [[Aleksey Zhuravlyov (politician)|Aleksey Zhuravlyov]] announced that the party will only support incumbent president Vladimir Putin in the election.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rodina.ru/s-ezd-partii/III-sezd-partii-chast-II-01072017/Doklad-Alekseya-ZHuravleva-na-III-Sezde-partii-RODINA|title=Доклад Алексея Журавлева на III Съезде партии "РОДИНА"|website=www.rodina.ru|access-date=2017-11-09}} On 11 December, the leader of [[Civic Platform (Russia)|Civic Platform]] [[Rifat Shaykhutdinov]] also said that his party will support Putin.{{Cite web|url=http://tass.ru/politika/4802523|title="Гражданская платформа" поддержит Путина на выборах президента России|website=ТАСС|access-date=2017-12-11}} On 24 December, the leader of [[A Just Russia]] [[Sergey Mironov]] commented that the party is not going to put forward a candidate. Senior party member Mikhail Yemelyanov confirmed that the party will support Putin's candidacy.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rbc.ru/politics/24/12/2017/5a3fde109a7947f1588036a9|title=«Справедливая Россия» поддержит Путина на выборах президента|website=РБК|access-date=2017-12-25}} ====Contested access==== Individuals who belong to a party without any seats in the State Duma had to collect 105,000 signatures to become candidates, while those running as independents had to collect 315,000 and also form a group of activists made up of at least 500 people.{{Cite news|url=https://meduza.io/news/2017/12/15/sovet-federatsii-ob-yavil-nachalo-kampanii-po-vyboram-prezidenta-rossii|title=Совет Федерации объявил начало кампании по выборам президента России|work=Meduza|access-date=2017-12-15|language=ru-RU}} Multiple political commentators, including former presidential hopeful [[Irina Khakamada]], talked about the difficulty of gathering signatures without the support of a political party, which casted doubt on many of the claims of the large number of people who said that they would run for president as independents.{{Cite news|url=https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/3442487|title=Госпожа претендент|date=2017-10-19|work=Газета "Коммерсантъ"|access-date=2017-11-09|pages=1}} However, according to [[Central Election Commission of Russia|CEC]] Chairwoman [[Ella Pamfilova]], the conditions for contested access candidates were easier than ever because they no longer had to collect 1,000,000 signatures. Pamfilova incorrectly predicted that there could be even more candidates in this election than there were in [[Russian presidential election, 2000|2000]] when the election was contested by 11 candidates (the largest number of candidates in the history of presidential elections in Russia).{{Cite news|url=http://tass.ru/politika/4808330|title=В ЦИК ожидают большого количества желающих баллотироваться в президенты|work=ТАСС|access-date=2017-12-13}} ===Primaries=== ====Party of Growth==== {{Main article|Party of Growth presidential primaries, 2017}} In July 2017, Party of Growth announced that it would hold primaries to nominate a presidential candidate. Four candidates participated in the primaries: [[Oksana Dmitriyeva]], [[Dmitry Potapenko]], [[Dmitry Marinichev]] and [[Alexander Huruji]]. Voting was conducted via the internet from August to November 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://primaries.rost.ru|title=Рост|website=primaries.rost.ru|language=ru|access-date=2018-02-09}} On 10 August 2017, the party's press secretary told the media that the results of the primaries will be taken into account at the party congress which will be held to decide the candidate for Party of Growth. However, the winner of the primaries would not guarantee themselves the right to run on behalf of the party.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rbc.ru/politics/10/08/2017/598c65619a79471ba8ab09c2?from=main|title=Члены Партии роста предложили Путину уйти с поста президента|website=РБК|access-date=2018-02-09}} On 26 November, it was announced that the party would nominate [[Boris Titov]], who was not involved in the primaries. According to a person from the party leadership, none of the proposed candidates were able to obtain sufficient support.{{Cite news|url=https://www.vedomosti.ru/politics/articles/2017/11/26/743019-titov-uchastii-viborah-prezidenta|title=Борис Титов объявил об участии в выборах президента России|last=Ведомости|date=2017-11-26|access-date=2018-02-09}} ====Left Front==== On 2 November 2017, the [[Left Front (Russia)|Left Front]] headed by [[Sergei Udaltsov]] started online primaries for the nomination of a single left-wing candidate. Primaries were held in two rounds, the first round took place from 2 to 23 November, and the second round - from 24 to 30 November. The first round included 77 candidates, among whom were representatives of various left-wing political parties and organizations, including [[Pavel Grudinin]], [[Yury Boldyrev]], [[Gennady Zyuganov]], [[Sergey Mironov]] (who later supported Vladimir Putin), [[Sergey Glazyev]], [[Zakhar Prilepin]], [[Viktor Anpilov]], [[Valery Zorkin]], [[Zhores Alferov]], [[Sergey Baburin]] (who later was nominated as a candidate from the party [[Russian All-People's Union]]), [[Natalia Lisitsyna]] (who was later nominated as a candidate from the [[Russian United Labour Front]]), [[Maxim Suraykin]] (who was nominated as a candidate from the [[Communists of Russia]]) and others.{{Cite web|url=https://www.leftfront.org/candidate2018/rules.php|title=Кандидат 2018 — Левый Фронт|website=Кандидат 2018 — Левый Фронт|language=ru-RU|access-date=2018-02-11}} Boldyrev and Grudinin made it through to the second round, which was won by Grudinin, who garnered 4,086 votes (58.4%).{{Cite web|url=https://www.leftfront.org/candidate2018/secondtour.php|title=Кандидат 2018 — Левый Фронт|website=Кандидат 2018 — Левый Фронт|language=ru-RU|access-date=2018-02-09}} At the end of December 2017, Grudinin was officially nominated as the candidate from the Communist Party. ====Third Force==== [[File:Праймериз Третья сила 2018.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Participants of the Third Force primaries]] The bloc Third Force held primaries among candidates from ten non-parliamentary parties to nominate presidential candidates. According to the organizers, the primaries would determine four presidential candidates representing different views.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ridus.ru/news/261782|title=Десять непарламентских партий объединились в блок «Третья сила»|last=Ридус|work=Ридус|access-date=2018-02-09|language=ru-ru}}{{Cite news|url=https://regnum.ru/news/2325629.html|title=«Третья сила» «выкристаллизирует» до четырех кандидатов в президенты РФ|work=ИА REGNUM|access-date=2018-02-09|language=ru-RU}} The official presentation of the candidates was held on 30 October 2017. The candidates included: [[Andrei Vladimirovich Bogdanov|Andrei Bogdanov]], [[Andrey Getmanov]], [[Olga Onishchenko]], [[Stanislav Polishchuk]], [[Sirazhdin Ramazanov]], [[Ildar Rezyapov]], [[Vyacheslav Smirnov]], [[Irina Volynets]] and [[Alexey Zolotukhin]].{{Cite news|url=https://ruposters.ru/news/28-10-2017/tretya|title=Третья сила|work=Ruposters.ru|access-date=2018-02-09|language=ru-RU}} However, the block failed to identify a clear winner, then all candidates, except for Olga Onishchenko has declared that they would participate in the elections. Later, however, all of the candidates refused to participate.{{Cite news|url=https://www.eg.ru/politics/427118/|title=Победители без побеждённых|work=EG.RU|access-date=2018-02-09|language=ru}}{{Cite news|url=http://rusplt.ru/news/irina-volyinets-okazalas-669285.html|title=Ирина Волынец отказалась баллотироваться в президенты|access-date=2018-02-09}}{{Cite news|url=https://rg.ru/2018/01/31/polishchuk-snial-svoiu-kandidaturu-s-vyborov-prezidenta.html|title=Полищук снял свою кандидатуру с выборов президента|date=2018-01-31|work=Российская газета|access-date=2018-02-09|language=ru}} ==Candidates== {{Main article|Russian presidential candidates, 2018}} These candidates have been officially registered by the CEC. Candidates are listed in the order they appeal on the ballot paper (alphabetical order in Russian).{{Cite web|url=http://www.cikrf.ru/analog/prezidentskiye-vybory-2018/kandidaty/|title=Кандидаты на должность Президента Российской Федерации|website=www.cikrf.ru|access-date=2018-02-11}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! colspan="3" style="width:20%;"| Candidate name, age,

([[Sergey Baburin presidential campaign, 2018|Campaign]] • [http://baburin2018.ru/ Website]) |On 22 December 2017, the [[Russian All-People's Union]] nominated Sergey Baburin as its presidential candidate.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20171222/1511547988.html|title="Российский общенародный союз" выдвинул Бабурина кандидатом в президенты|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2017-12-22|language=ru}} On 24 December Baburin filed registration documents with the CEC.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20171224/1511613603.html|title=Бабурин подал в ЦИК документы для выдвижения в президенты от своей партии|date=2017-12-24|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2017-12-25|language=ru}} The CEC rejected Baburin's bid on 25 December because it identified violations in the information provided regarding 18 of his party's 48 representatives.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20171225/1511707984.html|title=ЦИК предложил трем потенциальным кандидатам устранить нарушения при выдвижении|date=2017-12-25|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2017-12-26|language=ru}} Baburin resubmitted the documents and they were approved by the CEC.{{Cite news|url=http://tass.ru/politika/4852241|title=ЦИК разрешил Бабурину открыть избирательный счет и начать сбор подписей|work=ТАСС|access-date=2018-01-02|language=ru}} |7 February 2018{{cite news|title=ЦИК зарегистрировал Бабурина кандидатом на пост президента|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20180207/1514147021.html|accessdate=2018-02-07|publisher=РИА Новости|date=2018-02-07|language=ru}} |- | style="background:lavender;" |'''[[Pavel Grudinin]]'''
(57)
[[Communist Party of the Russian Federation|Communist Party]] |[[File:Pavel Grudinin Moscow asv2018-01 (cropped).jpg|130px]] |style="background-color:{{Communist Party of the Russian Federation/meta/color}};" | |'''Deputy of the [[Moscow Oblast Duma]]'''
(1997–2011) | [[File:GRU logo.png|200px]]
([[Pavel Grudinin presidential campaign, 2018|Campaign]] • [http://grudininkprf.ru/ Website]) |Despite the fact that Communist Party leader and perennial candidate [[Gennady Zyuganov]] said his nomination was supported by all leftist forces and he would participate in the elections on behalf of the party, the [[Zhigulyovsk]] branch of the party voted to supported the candidacy of [[Pavel Grudinin]], who also won the [https://www.leftfront.org/candidate2018/ primaries] of [[Left Front (Russia)|Left Front]], a coalition of left-wing parties with no representation in the [[State Duma]]. Grudinin did not deny his nomination from the Communist Party.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ng.ru/news/601241.html|title=КПРФ может выдвинуть в президенты главу "Совхоза имени Ленина" Грудинина|website=www.ng.ru|language=en|access-date=2017-12-01}} On 21 December 2017 it was reported that Zyuganov proposed to nominate Grudinin.{{Cite news|url=http://www.mk.ru/politics/2017/12/21/smi-kprf-mozhet-vydvinut-kandidatom-v-prezidenty-ne-zyuganova.html|title=СМИ: КПРФ может выдвинуть кандидатом в президенты не Зюганова|access-date=2017-12-25|language=ru-RU}} Initially the Communist Party and the National Patriotic Forces of Russia (NPFR) planned to nominate a single candidate: Grudinin (supported by the Communists) or Yury Boldyrev (supported by the NPFR). Boldyrev also participated in the primaries of Left Front in which he lost in the second round to Grudinin.{{Cite news|url=https://riafan.ru/1009629-ne-zyuganov-kprf-i-npsr-vydvinut-edinogo-kandidata-na-prezidentskie-vybory-2018|title=Не Зюганов: КПРФ и НПСР выдвинут единого кандидата на президентские выборы-2018|last=Громов|first=Алексей|work=Федеральное агентство новостей No.1|access-date=2017-12-25}} According to the Deputy [[Alexander Yushchenko]], Zyuganov was still among the candidates for the nomination. He named the other candidates as [[Yury Afonin]], [[Sergey Levchenko]] and [[Leonid Kalashnikov]]. On 22 December Zyuganov, Levchenko and Kalashnikov withdrew their bids, and Zyuganov rejected the candidacies of Afonin and Boldyrev, leaving Grudinin as the sole candidate.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rbc.ru/politics/23/12/2017/5a3d8a8e9a794796a648690c|title=Зюганов раскрыл ЦК партии причины отказа от президентской гонки|website=РБК|access-date=2017-12-23}} Grudinin was officially nominated at the party congress on 23 December.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20171223/1511588370.html|title=Жириновский назвал достойной кандидатуру Грудинина от КПРФ на пост президента|date=2017-12-23|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2017-12-25|language=ru}} Zyuganov is the head of Grudinin's presidential campaign.{{Cite news|url=https://nation-news.ru/334959-zyuganov-vozglavit-predvybornyi-shtab-kandidata-ot-kprf-grudinina|title=Зюганов возглавит предвыборный штаб кандидата от КПРФ Грудинина|last=Наумкина|first=Катерина|work=Народные Новости России|access-date=2017-12-25}} Grudinin filed registration documents with the CEC on 28 December {{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20171228/1511910479.html|title=ЦИК принял документы Грудинина для выдвижения кандидатом в президенты|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2018-01-02|language=ru}} and 9 January 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20180109/1512318714.html|title=ЦИК получил документы для регистрации Грудинина кандидатом в президенты|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2018-01-11|language=ru}} |12 January 2018{{Cite news|url=http://tass.ru/politika/4869293|title=ЦИК зарегистрировал выдвинутого КПРФ Грудинина кандидатом в президенты|work=ТАСС|access-date=2018-01-12|language=ru}} |- | style="background:lavender;" | '''[[Vladimir Zhirinovsky]]'''
(71)
[[Liberal Democratic Party of Russia|Liberal Democratic Party]] | [[File:Vladimir Zhirinovsky in 2015.jpg|130px]] | style="background-color:{{Liberal Democratic Party of Russia/meta/color}};" | | '''Deputy of the [[State Duma]]'''
(1993–present)
'''Leader of the Liberal Democratic Party'''
(1991–present) | ([[Vladimir Zhirinovsky presidential campaign, 2018|Campaign]]) | In June 2015 [[Vladimir Zhirinovsky]] said he plans to participate in presidential elections, but in July of the same year, the politician said that the [[Liberal Democratic Party of Russia|Liberal Democratic Party]], perhaps “will pick a more efficient person.”[http://www.rbc.ru/rbcfreenews/557f10c59a79472e6561290a Жириновский объявил о своем участии в выборах президента в 2018 году | Zhirinovsky declares his participation in 2018 presidential election]. RBK. Published 15 June 2015. Retrieved 7 May 2017. {{ru icon}}[http://rusnovosti.ru/posts/380798 Жириновский не исключил, что ЛДПР на выборах президента представит не он | Zhirivonsky doesn’t rule out someone else representing LDPR in election]. Life.ru. Published 23 July 2015. Retrieved 7 May 2017. {{ru icon}} Already in March 2016, he announced the names of those were likely to be nominated as a candidate from the Liberal Democratic Party. This included [[List of Deputy Chairmen of the State Duma|Deputy Chairman of the State Duma]] [[Igor Lebedev (politician)|Igor Lebedev]] or deputies [[Mikhail Degtyarev]], [[Yaroslav Nilov]] and [[Alexei Didenko]].[https://life.ru/860843 Жириновский пойдёт на выборы президента с четырьмя преемниками | Zhirinovsky to go into election with four successors]. Life.ru. Published 2 March 2016. Retrieved 7 May 2017. {{ru icon}} On 28 October 2016, the LDPR’s official website released a statement announcing that the party will nominate Zhirinovsky as their presidential candidate.[http://ldpr.ru/events/Zhirinovsky_I_will_protect_Russian_everywhere/ Владимир Жириновский: я буду защищать русских везде | I will protect Russians everywhere]. LDPR official website. Published 28 October 2016. Retrieved 7 May 2017. {{ru icon}}[http://www.kommersant.ru/doc/3130177 Владимир Жириновский снова собрался в президенты | Vladimir Zhirinovsky again running for presidency]. [[Kommersant]]. Published 28 October 2016. Retrieved 7 May 2017. {{ru icon}} This is the fifth time that he is running for president since the breakup of the Soviet Union (and sixth overall). Zhirinovsky was officially nominated by his party at its 31st congress on 20 December 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rbc.ru/rbcfreenews/5a3950ad9a794771556fc463?from=newsfeed|title=Жириновский в шестой раз поборется за пост президента России|website=РБК|access-date=2017-12-20}} He submitted to the CEC some of the documents required for registration the next day,{{Cite web|url=https://www.rbc.ru/rbcfreenews/5a3b8a5a9a79476ce7ec0b18?from=newsfeed|title=Жириновский подал в ЦИК документы на выдвижение кандидатом в президенты|website=РБК|access-date=2017-12-21}} and the rest of them on 27 December.{{Cite news|url=http://tass.ru/politika/4847856|title=В ЦИК поступили документы для регистрации Жириновского кандидатом в президенты России|work=ТАСС|access-date=2018-01-09|language=ru}} At 71, Zhirinovsky is the oldest person to run for president in Russia.{{Cite news|url=http://tass.ru/info/4844712|title=Президентские выборы в РФ: статистические показатели. Досье|work=ТАСС|access-date=2018-01-14|language=ru}} |29 December 2017{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018/20171229/1511979294.html|title=Жириновский стал первым официально зарегистрированным кандидатом в президенты|date=2017-12-29|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2017-12-29|language=ru}} |- | style="background:lavender;" | '''[[Vladimir Putin]]'''

([[Vladimir Putin presidential campaign, 2018|Campaign]] • [http://putin2018.ru/ Website]) |On 6 December 2017 Vladimir Putin announced that he will run for a second consecutive term.{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-42256140|title=Putin to run again for Russia president|date=2017-12-06|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-12-06|language=en-GB}} Putin announced that he would run as an independent at his annual press conference on 14 December.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-putin-opposition/putin-says-will-run-as-independent-candidate-for-new-kremlin-term-idUSKBN1E812L|title=Putin says will run as independent candidate for new Kremlin term|date=2017-12-14|work=Reuters|access-date=2017-12-14}} Putin's action group officially put forward his nomination in Moscow on 26 December.[https://www.rferl.org/a/russia-putin-officially-nominated-presidency/28940192.html Celebrity-Laden Action Group Officially Nominates Putin As Candidate For Russian Presidency] - RFE/RL, December 26, 2017 Putin filed registration documents with the CEC the next day.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20171227/1511812468.html|title=Путин подал документы в Центризбирком|last=|first=|date=|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2018-01-06|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=ru}} The CEC approved his documents on 28 December.{{Cite news|url=http://tass.ru/politika/4849734|title=ЦИК зарегистрировал уполномоченных Путина и дал ему разрешение открыть избирательный счет|work=ТАСС|access-date=2018-01-06|language=ru}} On 29 January Putin handed over the signatures to the CEC. By 2 February they had been verified - only 232 signatures were deemed invalid.{{Cite news|url=http://tass.ru/politika/4925843|title=ЦИК проверил подписи в поддержку Путина|work=ТАСС|access-date=2018-02-11|language=ru}} |6 February 2018[https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/3540870 ЦИК зарегистрировал Владимира Путина кандидатом в президенты] |- | style="background:lavender;" | '''[[Ksenia Sobchak]]'''

(2012–present) |([[Maxim Suraykin presidential campaign, 2018|Campaign]]) | The Central Committee of the [[Communists of Russia]] party announced the nomination of its chairman Maxim Suraikin as its candidate for the election in February 2017. Suraikin stated that he aims to at least come in second place, and defeat Zyuganov's larger Communist Party of the Russian Federation.[https://www.gazeta.ru/politics/news/2017/02/01/n_9635171.shtml Партия «Коммунисты России» определилась с кандидатом в президенты | Party "Communists of Russia" decide on a candidate for the presidency]. Gazeta.ru. Published 1 February 2017. Retrieved 7 May 2017. {{ru icon}} CR nominated Suraikin at the party congress in Moscow on 24 December.{{Cite web|url=http://komros.info/News/news_10659.html|title=КОММУНИСТЫ РОССИИ - ОФИЦИАЛЬНЫЙ САЙТ / Новости / России необходим сталинский президент-коммунист! 6-й съезд Партии КОММУНИСТЫ РОССИИ выдвинул ТОВАРИЩА МАКСИМА кандидатом в президенты страны!|website=komros.info|access-date=2017-12-25}} He filed registration documents with the CEC on the same day.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20171224/1511614573.html|title=Сурайкин подал в ЦИК документы для выдвижения в президенты|date=2017-12-24|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2017-12-25|language=ru}} Suraikin's documents were approved by the CEC on 25 December.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20171225/1511676749.html|title=ЦИК утвердил документы Сурайкина на выдвижение в президенты|date=2017-12-25|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2017-12-26|language=ru}} |8 February 2018[https://rg.ru/2018/02/08/cik-zaregistriroval-maksima-surajkina-kandidatom-v-prezidenty-rossii.html ЦИК зарегистрировал Максима Сурайкина кандидатом в президенты России] |- | style="background:lavender;" | '''[[Boris Titov]]'''

fontsize:S text:"Beginning of election campaign" pos:(1384,30) textcolor:black fontsize:S text:"Election" ==Campaigning== === Sergey Baburin === {{Main article|Sergey Baburin presidential campaign, 2018}} [[File:Бабурин 2018 (2).png|250px|thumb|Baburin campaign logo]] [[Sergey Baburin]] was nominated at the party congress on 22 December 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20171222/1511547988.html|title="Российский общенародный союз" выдвинул Бабурина кандидатом в президенты|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2017-12-22|language=ru}} On 24 December Baburin filed registration documents with the CEC.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20171224/1511613603.html|title=Бабурин подал в ЦИК документы для выдвижения в президенты от своей партии|date=2017-12-24|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2017-12-25|language=ru}} But CEC rejected Baburin's bid on 25 December because it identified violations in the information provided regarding 18 of his party's 48 representatives.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20171225/1511707984.html|title=ЦИК предложил трем потенциальным кандидатам устранить нарушения при выдвижении|date=2017-12-25|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2017-12-26|language=ru}} On 29 December Baburin again resubmitted the documents and they were approved by the CEC.{{Cite news|url=http://tass.ru/politika/4852241|title=ЦИК разрешил Бабурину открыть избирательный счет и начать сбор подписей|work=ТАСС|access-date=2018-01-02|language=ru}} Russian All-People's Union started to collect signatures in support Baburin on 9 January 2018. Signatures were collected in 56 [[federal subjects of Russia|federal subjects]].[https://itpresident.info/2018/01/sergej-baburin-nachal-sobirat-podpisi/ СЕРГЕЙ БАБУРИН НАЧАЛ СОБИРАТЬ ПОДПИСИ][https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20180109/1512305277.html?inj=1 Кандидат в президенты Бабурин рассказал о своей предвыборной кампании] On 30 January 2018 Sergey Baburin handed over the signatures to the CEC. When testing revealed only 3.28% of invalid signatures, due to which Sergey Baburin was admitted to the election.[http://tass.ru/politika/4912088 Бабурин сдаст подписи для регистрации кандидатом в президенты РФ 30 января][http://www.interfax.ru/russia/598520 ЦИК зарегистрирует кандидатами в президенты Путина, Явлинского, Титова и Бабурина] === Pavel Grudinin === {{Main article|Pavel Grudinin presidential campaign, 2018}} [[File:GRU logo.png|250px|thumb|Grudinin campaign logo]] At the end of November [[Pavel Grudinin]] won the [https://www.leftfront.org/candidate2018/ primaries] of [[Left Front (Russia)|Left Front]], a coalition of left-wing parties with no representation in the [[State Duma]]. Some branch of the [[Communist Party of the Russian Federation|Communist Party]] voted to supported the candidacy of Grudinin did not deny his nomination from the Communist Party.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ng.ru/news/601241.html|title=КПРФ может выдвинуть в президенты главу "Совхоза имени Ленина" Грудинина|website=www.ng.ru|language=en|access-date=2017-12-01}} Despite the fact that in early November the First Secretary of the Communist party [[Gennady Zyuganov]], said that his nomination is supported by all left-wing organizations, which the media felt that this was the official statement Zyuganov to participate in the election. However, later, Zyuganov denied this, saying that the official decision will be made at the party Congress in December. On 21 December it was reported that Zyuganov proposed to nominate Grudinin.{{Cite news|url=http://www.mk.ru/politics/2017/12/21/smi-kprf-mozhet-vydvinut-kandidatom-v-prezidenty-ne-zyuganova.html|title=СМИ: КПРФ может выдвинуть кандидатом в президенты не Зюганова|access-date=2018-01-09|language=ru-RU}} Initially the Communist Party and the National Patriotic Forces of Russia (NPFR) planned to nominate a single candidate: Grudinin (supported by the Communists) or Yury Boldyrev (supported by the NPFR). It should be noted that Boldyrev also participated in the primaries of Left Front in which he lost in the second round to Grudinin.{{Cite news|url=https://riafan.ru/1009629-ne-zyuganov-kprf-i-npsr-vydvinut-edinogo-kandidata-na-prezidentskie-vybory-2018|title=Не Зюганов: КПРФ и НПСР выдвинут единого кандидата на президентские выборы-2018|last=Громов|first=Алексей|work=Федеральное агентство новостей No.1|access-date=2018-01-09}} According to the Deputy Alexander Yushchenko, Gennady Zyuganov was still among the candidates for the nomination. He named the other candidates as [[Yury Afonin]], [[Sergey Levchenko]] and [[Leonid Kalashnikov]]. On 22 December Zyuganov, Levchenko and Kalashnikov withdrew their bids, and Zyuganov rejected the candidacies of Afonin and Boldyrev, leaving Grudinin as the sole candidate.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rbc.ru/politics/23/12/2017/5a3d8a8e9a794796a648690c|title=Зюганов раскрыл ЦК партии причины отказа от президентской гонки|website=РБК|access-date=2017-12-23}} Grudinin was officially selected as the presidential candidate from the Communist Party at its congress on 23 December.{{Cite news|url=https://ren.tv/novosti/2017-12-23/sezd-kprf-utverdil-kandidaturu-grudinina-na-vyborah-prezidenta-rf|title=Съезд КПРФ утвердил кандидатуру Грудинина на выборах президента РФ|date=2017-12-23|work=РЕН ТВ|access-date=2018-01-09}} ===Alexei Navalny=== [[File:Навальный 2018.png|150px|thumb|Navalny campaign logo]] {{Main|Alexei Navalny presidential campaign, 2018}} [[Russian opposition]] figure and anti-corruption blogger [[Alexei Navalny]] started his presidential campaign on 13 December 2016.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wkN8sSrUbdY Пора выбирать: Алексей Навальный — кандидат в президенты России] — via YouTube. Published 2 March 2017. Retrieved 30 April 2017. {{ru icon}} In early 2017, he traveled to different cities across Russia to open campaign offices and meet with his supporters, despite his involvement in ongoing legal cases that may bar him from running. As noted in an article by ''[[Newsweek]]'' and by the former [[Presidential Administration of Russia|Russian presidential administration]] adviser [[Gleb Pavlovsky]],Tumakova, Irina, and Pavlovsky, Gleb (22 April 2017) [http://www.fontanka.ru/2017/04/21/165/ «Навальный ударил, а Кремль залез в угол и плюётся»]. Fontanka.ru. Retrieved 30 April 2017. {{ru icon}} the American-style campaign by Navalny is unprecedented in modern Russia as most candidates do not start campaigning until a few months before the election. The primary focus of Navalny's campaign is combating corruption within the current government under [[Vladimir Putin]] and [[Prime Minister of Russia|Prime Minister]] [[Dmitry Medvedev]].Bennetts, Marc (17 April 2017). [http://www.newsweek.com/2017/04/28/alexei-navalny-russia-vladimir-putin-donald-trump-corruption-protests-moscow-585004.html Alexei Navalny: Is Russia's Anti-Corruption Crusader Vladimir Putin's Kryptonite?]. ''[[Newsweek]]''. Retrieved 30 April 2017. On March 2, Navalny published a documentary on YouTube titled ''[[He Is Not Dimon To You]]'', detailing the corrupt dealings of Prime Minister Medvedev.Tamkin, Emily (2 March 2017). [https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/03/02/navalnys-anti-corruption-fund-accuses-medvedev-of-secret-massive-estate/ Navalny's Anti-Corruption Fund Accuses Medvedev of Secret Massive Estate]. [[Foreign Policy (magazine)|Foreign Policy]]. Retrieved 30 April 2017.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qrwlk7_GF9g&t=924s Он вам не Димон] — via YouTube. Published 2 March 2017. Retrieved 30 April 2017. He then called for [[2017 Russian protests|mass rallies]] to be held on March 26 to bring attention to this after the government made no response to the documentary, which over 100,000 people were said to have attended across the country.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-Kh0zUkX7cs 26 марта все на улицу: он нам не Димон] — via YouTube. Published 23 March 2017. Retrieved 30 April 2017. {{ru icon}}[http://www.rbc.ru/politics/26/03/2017/58d7c6f39a7947448a1a3f45 Кремль на развилке: каковы последствия протестных акций по всей России]. Rbk.ru. Published 26 March 2017. Retrieved 30 April 2017. {{ru icon}} The March 26 rally was the largest protest held in Russia since the [[2011-2012 Russian protests|protests in 2011]].Filipov, David (March 26, 2017). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/russian-police-arrest-protesters-at-nationwide-anti-corruption-rallies/2017/03/26/11208e46-10a1-11e7-aa57-2ca1b05c41b8_story.html Russian police arrest anti-corruption leader Navalny, hundreds more in nationwide rallies]. ''[[Washington Post]]''. Accessed April 30, 2017. Since then Navalny has called for another protest to be held on [[Russia Day]], which is June 12.{{cite web|url = http://www.rbc.ru/politics/12/04/2017/58ee11909a7947c7ab8e444d|title = Навальный сообщил о подготовке новой протестной акции|author = Anastasia Uditskaya, Sergei Vitko, Evgeniya Kuznetsova|date = 12 April 2017|publisher = Rbk.ru|accessdate = 14 April 2017}} {{ru icon}} On his website, Navalny lists the main principles of his presidential program: combating government corruption, improving infrastructure and living standards in Russia, decentralizing power from Moscow, developing the economy instead of remaining in isolation from the West, and reforming the judicial system.[https://2018.navalny.com/platform/ https://2018.navalny.com/platform/ Platform] {{ru icon}}. Navalny 2018 website. Retrieved 30 April 2017. His more specific economic proposals include instituting a [[minimum wage]],{{cite web|url=https://www.gazeta.ru/business/2016/12/21/10440995.shtml|title=Экономика не выдержит Навального|author=Pyotr Orekhin|date=21 December 2016|publisher=Gazetta.ru|accessdate=30 April 2017}} {{ru icon}} lowering prices of apartments and reducing bureaucracy of home construction, making healthcare and education free, lowering taxes for many citizens, taxing the gains from [[privatization in Russia|privatization]], decentralization of financial management and increase in local governance, increasing transparency in state-owned firms, implementing work visas for [[Central Asia]]n migrants coming into the country for work, and increasing economic cooperation with western European states.{{cite web|url=http://www.saleksashenko.com/2016/12/blog-post_17.html|title=Alexei Navalny's Program. Economist's Analysis|author=Sergei Aleksashenko|date=15 December 2016|publisher=Republic|accessdate=30 April 2017}} {{ru icon}} In April 2017, it was reported that Navalny's campaign staff had collected more than 300,000 pledged signatures from people across 40 regions of Russia electronically.{{cite web|url=http://www.mk.ru/politics/2017/04/18/navalnyy-sobral-neobkhodimye-300-tys-podpisey-dlya-vyborov-prezidenta.html|title=Навальный собрал необходимые 300 тыс подписей для выборов президента|author=Arseny Tomin|date=18 April 2017|publisher=Moskovsky Komsomolets|accessdate=30 April 2017}} {{ru icon}} More than 75,000 people signed up to volunteer for his campaign and nearly $700,000 has been donated.Rothrock, Kevin (25 April 2017). [https://globalvoices.org/2017/04/25/how-alexey-navalny-abandoned-russian-nationalism/ How Alexey Navalny Abandoned Russian Nationalism]. Global Voices. Retrieved 1 May 2017. However, his eligibility was put into question by his five-year suspended sentence for accused embezzlement of timber from the company Kirovles, back when Navalny had been working as an aide to Governor [[Nikita Belykh]] of the [[Kirov Oblast]]. The [[Russian Supreme Court]] overturned his sentence in November 2016 after the [[European Court of Human Rights]] determined that Navalny's rights were violated and sent it back to a district court in the city of [[Kirov, Kirov Oblast|Kirov]] for review.[http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-37999199 Russia Navalny: Supreme court overturns conviction for fraud]. [[BBC]]. Published 16 November 2016. Retrieved 4 May 2017. In February 2017, the district court upheld Navalny's suspended sentence.[https://themoscowtimes.com/news/russian-activist-navalny-sentenced-in-kirovles-case-57038 Russian Activist Navalny Given 5-Year Suspended Sentence in Kirovles Retrial]. [[The Moscow Times]]. Published 8 February 2017. Retrieved 2 May 2017. The [[Constitution of Russia]] does not allow convicted criminals to run for office, so it is believed his candidacy will be rejected. Navalny promised to appeal the result to the ECHR and said he will continue campaigning,Yegorov, Oleg (3 May 2017). [https://rbth.com/politics_and_society/2017/05/03/russias-opposition-figure-cannot-run-for-president_755666 Russia's opposition figure ‘cannot run for president']. [[Russia Beyond the Headlines]]. Published 3 May 2017. while in early May the deputy head of the Russian CEC commented that he would not be allowed to run unless the sentence is overturned.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-election-navalny-idUSKBN17Z21J Kremlin critic Navalny can't run for presidency - election official]. [[Reuters]]. Published 3 May 2017. Retrieved 3 May 2017. In August, the head of the CEC, Ella Pamfilova, reinforced this sentiment, saying that it would “take a miracle” for Navalny to be granted permission to run.{{Cite news|url=http://www.rbc.ru/politics/15/08/2017/5992abdc9a794739354128d4?from=main|title=Памфилова рассказала о двух возможных вариантах регистрации Навального|work=РБК|access-date=2017-11-09}}. She cited two scenarios in which Navalny could run - if his conviction is overturned, or in the event that federal election law is urgently changed to allow those with criminal convictions to run. Pamfilova added that the possibility of either scenario unfolding was “extremely low”. Panfliova later commented that Navalny could legally run for president by “some time in 2028”, i.e. ten years after his sentence expires.{{Cite news|url=http://www.rbc.ru/politics/17/10/2017/59e5cdf69a7947840201cb10|title=Глава ЦИК напутствовала Навального на выборы фразой «флаг в руки»|work=РБК|access-date=2017-11-09}} The [[Memorial (society)|Memorial Human Rights Center]] recognized Navalny as a [[political prisoner]].{{cite web|url=http://echo.msk.ru/news/1117596-echo.html |title=Радио ЭХО Москвы :: Новости / Правозащитный центр Мемориал признал Алексея Навального политическим заключенным |publisher=Echo.msk.ru |accessdate=July 19, 2013}} Members of the Navalny campaign have been harassed and detained by the police, including his chief of staff Leonid Volkov, who was sentenced to thirty days in jail in early December for organising an unauthorized rally (requests for rallies in city centers are often denied in Russia{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}}) in [[Nizhny Novgorod]].Walker, Shaun (7 December 2017). [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/dec/07/navalny-army-russians-risking-all-to-oppose-vladimir-putin Navalny's army: the Russians risking all to oppose Vladimir Putin]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. Retrieved 8 December 2017.[https://www.rferl.org/a/volkov-navalny-campaign-chief-30-days-jail/28890814.html Navalny's Campaign Chief Gets 30 Days In Jail In Nizhny Novgorod]. [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]. Published 1 December 2017. Retrieved 8 December 2017. Navalny published his election manifesto on 13 December 2017, two days prior to the official start of campaigning.{{Cite news|url=https://meduza.io/short/2017/12/13/prezidentskaya-programma-alekseya-navalnogo-v-odnoy-kartinke|title=Президентская программа Алексея Навального. В одной картинке|work=Meduza|access-date=2017-12-13|language=ru-RU}} He officially submitted his documents for registration as a candidate on 24 December 2017, and was rejected by the CEC the following day due to his conviction. Later that same day, 25 December, Navalny called on his supporters to boycott the election in response. Mass street protests are planned for 28 January 2018.{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-42479909 |title=Russian presidential election: Alexei Navalny barred from competing |date=December 25, 2017 |website=www.bbc.com |publisher=BBC |access-date=December 25, 2017}} ===Vladimir Putin=== [[File:Putin 2018 logo (2).jpg|200px|thumb|Putin campaign logo]] {{Main article|Vladimir Putin presidential campaign, 2018}} [[Vladimir Putin]] announced his run on 6 December 2017, during his speech at the [[GAZ]] automobile plant.{{Cite news|url=https://rg.ru/2017/12/06/vladimir-putin-ia-budu-ballotirovatsia-na-post-prezidenta-rf.html|title=Владимир Путин: Я буду баллотироваться на пост президента РФ|date=2017-12-06|work=Российская газета|access-date=2017-12-25|language=ru}}{{Cite news|url=https://lenta.ru/articles/2017/12/06/putin_start/|title=Выбрал сцену|access-date=2017-12-25}} [[A Just Russia]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.rbc.ru/politics/25/12/2017/5a40bc719a79470d6296e296?from=newsfeed|title=Миронов призвал не допустить в новое правительство «либеральных людоедов»|website=РБК|access-date=2017-12-25}} [[Civic Platform (Russia)|Civic Platform]],{{Cite web|url=http://tass.ru/politika/4802523|title="Гражданская платформа" поддержит Путина на выборах президента России|website=ТАСС|access-date=2017-12-11}} [[Russian Ecological Party "The Greens"|The Greens]],{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018/20171226/1511741757.html|title=Партия "Зеленые" завила, что поддержит Путина на выборах президента|date=2017-12-26|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2017-12-26|language=ru}} [[Great Fatherland Party]],[https://партиявеликоеотечество.рф/v-moskve-sostoyalos-rabochee-soveshhanie-tsentralnogo-komiteta-partii-velikoe-otechestvo Партия Великое Отечество на выборах Президента поддержит В.В. Путина] [[Labor Party of Russia|Labor Party]],{{Cite news|url=https://riafan.ru/1007903-trudovaya-partiya-rossii-podderzhit-kandidaturu-putina-na-vyborakh-2018|title=Трудовая партия России поддержит кандидатуру Путина на выборах-2018|last=Плющев|first=Геннадий|work=Федеральное агентство новостей No.1|access-date=2017-12-25}} [[Russian Party of Pensioners for Social Justice|Party of Pensioners]],[Party of Pensioners «Партия пенсионеров» не станет выдвигать кандидата на выборах президента РФ] [[Patriots of Russia]],{{Cite news|url=http://tass.ru/politika/4790323|title="Патриоты России" намерены поддержать Путина на выборах президента|work=ТАСС|access-date=2017-12-25|language=ru}} [[Rodina (political party)|Rodina]],{{Cite news|url=https://regnum.ru/news/2354141.html|title=Лидер «Родины» заявил о поддержке кандидатуры Путина на выборах - ИА REGNUM|work=ИА REGNUM|access-date=2017-12-25|language=ru-RU}} and [[United Russia]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.mk.ru/politics/2017/12/06/edinaya-rossiya-podderzhit-kandidaturu-putina-na-vyborakh-prezidenta.html|title="Единая Россия" поддержит кандидатуру Путина на выборах президента|access-date=2017-12-25|language=ru-RU}} have endorsed his presidential bid. === Ksenia Sobchak === [[File:Sobchak 2018 logo.png|200px|thumb|Sobchak campaign logo]] {{Main article|Ksenia Sobchak presidential campaign, 2018}} Rumors about the nomination of Ksenia Sobchak in the 2018 election appeared a month before she officially announced that she would run for president.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/russia-presidential-election-female-candidate/28711576.html|title=A Female Candidate For A 'Predictable Election'? Kremlin Floats Women Challengers To Putin|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|access-date=2018-01-09}} Sobchak officially announced that she would run for president on 19 October 2017, in a [[YouTube]] video. In the video, Sobchak said she is the candidate “against all”, because since the [[Russian presidential election, 2004|2004 election]], the “against all” option (or “none of the above” as it is more commonly known in English-speaking countries) has been excluded from the ballot, and Sobchak wants to give people the opportunity to again vote “against all”. At the same time, Sobchak said she will withdraw her candidacy if [[Alexey Navalny]] is registered as a candidate by the [[Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation|Central Election Commission]].{{Cite news|url=https://tvrain.ru/teleshow/sobchak_zhivem/esli_navalnogo-447976/|title=«Если Навального зарегистрируют, я сниму свою кандидатуру»: первое интервью кандидата в президенты Ксении Собчак|last=Inc.|first=TV Rain,|access-date=2018-01-09}} Originally Sobchak put herself forward as an [[Independent politician|independent]] candidate. In this case she would have had to collect at least 300,000 signatures in order to be admitted to the election. Soon after, however, Sobchak’s campaign team said that would be nominated by a political party, namely the [[People’s Freedom Party]] or [[Civic Initiative]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.rbc.ru/politics/30/10/2017/59f64e849a794746fa903ce6|title=Штаб Собчак обсудил три схемы выдвижения в президенты|website=РБК|access-date=2018-01-09}} On 15 November 2017, it was announced that Sobchak will be nominated by CivicInitiative at its congress in December.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rbc.ru/politics/15/11/2017/5a0c6fbe9a7947295ef723ce|title=Ксения Собчак пойдет на выборы от партии бывшего министра|website=РБК|access-date=2018-01-09}} On 23 December 2017, at Civic Initiative's congress Sobchak was officially nominated for president. On the same day, she joined the party.{{Citation|title=Ксения Собчак выдвинута кандидатом в президенты РФ от «Гражданской инициативы». Новости. Первый канал|url=https://www.1tv.ru/news/2017-12-23/338437-kseniya_sobchak_vydvinuta_kandidatom_v_prezidenty_rf_ot_grazhdanskoy_initsiativy|language=ru-RU|accessdate=2018-01-09}} Sobchak’s team began gathering signatures in support of her candidacy on 27 December, soon after her registration documents were approved by the CEC.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20171227/1511801048.html|title=Команда Собчак начала сбор подписей в ее поддержку на выборах президента|date=2017-12-27|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2018-01-09|language=ru}} === Maxim Suraykin === {{Main article|Maxim Suraykin presidential campaign, 2018}} In December 2017, it became known that the party of Communists of Russia nominated Maxim Suraykin as presidential candidate.[https://ria.ru/politics/20161225/1484555209.html "Коммунисты России" намерены выдвинуть кандидата на выборах президента] On 28 May 2017, the Plenum of the Central Committee of the Communists of Russia took the decision on nomination of Maxim Suraykin as presidential candidate. In November 2017, Maxim Suraykin was one of the candidates proposed by the [[Left Front (Russia)|Left Front]] as a single candidate from the left opposition. The results of the voting on the website of the Left Front Suraikin won 59 votes.[https://www.leftfront.org/candidate2018/ ВЫБОРЫ КАНДИДАТА В ПРЕЗИДЕНТЫ ОТ ЛЕВЫХ СИЛ] On 24 December Maxim Suraykin were officially nominated at the Communists Russia National Convention. On the same day he submitted to the [[Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation|Central Election Commission]].[http://tass.ru/politika/4839331 "Коммунисты России" выдвинули Сурайкина кандидатом на выборы президента РФ] === Boris Titov === [[File:Titov 2018 logo.png|250px|thumb|Titov campaign logo]] {{Main article|Boris Titov presidential campaign, 2018}} Initially the [[Party of Growth]] conducted [[Party of Growth presidential primaries, 2017|primaries]] which were attended by four candidates: [[Oksana Dmitriyeva]], [[Dmitry Potapenko]], [[Dmitry Marinichev]] and [[Alexander Khurudzhi]].{{Cite web|url=https://primaries.rost.ru|title=Рост|website=primaries.rost.ru|language=ru|access-date=2018-01-09}} Boris Titov did not participate in the primaries. However, at the meeting of the federal council of the party it was decided to nominate Titov. According to a person from the party leadership, none of the proposed candidates were able to obtain sufficient support.{{Cite news|url=https://www.vedomosti.ru/politics/articles/2017/11/26/743019-titov-uchastii-viborah-prezidenta|title=Борис Титов объявил об участии в выборах президента России|last=Ведомости|date=2017-11-26|access-date=2018-01-09}} According to Titov, the main task of participation in election is to promote the party's Growth Strategy economic program, which was prepared by the [[Pyotr Stolypin|Stolypin]] Club and presented to [[President of Russia|President]] [[Vladimir Putin]] in May 2017. During the campaign Titov and his team intend to travel around the country to promote the program.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rbc.ru/rbcfreenews/5a1a8d779a7947327c7cf025|title=Титов назвал главную задачу своего выдвижения на выборы президента России|website=РБК|access-date=2018-01-09}} Titov was officially nominated by his party on December 21.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rbc.ru/rbcfreenews/5a3a8b8b2ae596a9018cee7a|title=Партия роста выдвинула в президенты омбудсмена Бориса Титова|website=РБК|access-date=2017-12-21}} He submitted to the CEC the documents required for registration the next day.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20171222/1511503043.html|title=Титов подал в ЦИК документы для выдвижения кандидатом в президенты|date=2017-12-22|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2017-12-22|language=ru}} Titov’s documents were approved by the CEC on 25 December, which meant that he could begin collecting signatures.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20171225/1511671360.html|title=ЦИК утвердил документы Титова на выдвижение в президенты|date=2017-12-25|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2018-01-09|language=ru}} A party spokesman commented that the collection signatures in support of Titov will begin in early January 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20171225/1511691419.html|title=В "Партии роста" рассказали, когда начнут сбор подписей в поддержку Титова|date=20171225T1802+0300Z|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2018-01-19|language=ru}} === Grigory Yavlinsky === [[File:Yavlinsky 2018 1.png|300px|thumb|Yavlinsky campaign logo]] {{main|Grigory Yavlinsky presidential campaign, 2018}} Economist Grigory Yavlinsky announced his presidential bid in February 2016 as the candidate for the liberal party [[Yabloko]], though suggestions that he would run were first voiced in 2013 after he was barred from taking part in the [[Russian presidential election, 2012|2012 election]].[http://www.interfax.com/newsinf.asp?id=396435 Yabloko plans to nominate Yavlinsky again in the 2018 presidential election]. [[Interfax]]. Published 17 February 2013. Retrieved 3 May 2017. His policies mainly focus on improving the economic situation through governance reforms and stopping involvement in conflicts.[http://eng.yabloko.ru/?p=16397 Yavlinsky's campaign for President of Russia picks up]. Yabloko website. Published 23 February 2017. Retrieved 2 May 2017. He was nominated by the party leader, [[Emilia Slabunova]], who stressed the need to unite all "democratic forces" behind one candidate and noted his political experience, and also received an endorsement from opposition politician [[Vladimir Ryzhkov]]. Yavlinsky had previously run in the [[Russian presidential election, 1996|1996]] and [[Russian presidential election, 2000|2000]] presidential elections, getting 7.4% of the vote in the former.[https://www.rt.com/politics/333964-veteran-russian-liberal-yavlinsky-announces/ Veteran Russian liberal Yavlinsky announces presidential ambitions]. [[RT (TV network)|RT]]. Published 29 February 2017. Retrieved 2 May 2017. He spoke at a party forum announcing the start of the campaign in February 2017. Among the other proposals he made were to give out several acres of free land to families so they can build home there and develop it, which he said would house 15 million families,[https://rusreality.com/2017/03/21/yavlinsky-spoke-about-his-election-program-for-the-elections-2018/ Yavlinsky spoke about his election program for the elections-2018]. Russian Reality. Published 21 March 2017. Retrieved 3 May 2017. and to turn the [[Russian Armed Forces]] into a fully professional military by abolishing [[conscription in Russia|conscription]].Bolgova, Ekaterina (4 February 2017). [http://m.kp.ru/online/news/2647227/ Партия «Яблоко» объявила о старте предвыборной кампании Явлинского | Yabloko Party announced the start of Yavlinsky's election campaign]. ''[[Komsomolskaya Pravda]]''. Retrieved 2 May 2017. {{ru icon}}. In March 2017, Yavlinsky stated that he will be visiting several major cities in fifteen different regions across the country to raise support. He used Alexei Navalny's recent tour of different cities as an example, refusing to use the traditional model of campaigning a few months before the election. Since he is unable to visit more locations, Slabunova, the leader of Yabloko, and Nikolai Rybakov, his chief of staff, will go to other cities to campaign as well.Gorbachev, Alexei (21 March 2017). [http://www.ng.ru/politics/2017-03-21/3_6953_yavlinsky.html Явлинский отказался от традиционной предвыборной кампании | Yavlinsky refused a traditional election campaign]. Nezavisimaya Gazetta. Retrieved 2 May 2017. {{ru icon}} On 1 November 2017, Yabloko launched the official website of Yavlinsky's campaign.{{Cite news|url=https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/3455552|title=Григорию Явлинскому помогут Михеич и Алексеич|date=2017-01-11|work=Коммерсантъ|access-date=2017-11-09}} === Vladimir Zhirinovsky === {{Main article|Vladimir Zhirinovsky presidential campaign, 2018}} [[Vladimir Zhirinovsky]] announced his participation in the presidential elections on 28 October 2016 as the candidate for the [[Liberal Democratic Party of Russia|Liberal Democratic Party]]. In the event of his election, Zhirinovsky promised to amend the [[Constitution of Russia]] and to radically change the policies of the country. In particular, Zhirinovsky promised to abolish the federal structure of Russia and to return to the [[Governorate (Russia)|Governorates]], rename the post of "[[President of Russia]]" to the "Supreme Ruler of Russia" and to restore Russia's borders to the borders of the [[USSR]] as of 1985. In March 2017, Zhirinovsky promised to declare a [[general amnesty]] if elected president.{{cite web|url=https://ria.ru/society/20170322/1490546468.html|title=Жириновский обещает всеобщую амнистию в случае победы на выборах президента|date=22 March 2017|publisher=|accessdate=24 June 2017}} ==Debates== On 14 February 2018, the CEC set the schedule for the distribution of airtime for presidential candidates.{{Cite web|url=https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/3548494|title=Центризбирком распределил время для дебатов между СМИ|date=2018-02-14|access-date=2018-02-28}} Debates will take place on five federal TV channels: [[Russia 1]], [[Russia 24]], [[Channel One Russia|Channel One]], [[TV Centre (Russia)|TV Center]] and [[Public Television of Russia|PTR]], as well as on three radio stations: [[Radio Rossii]], [[Radio Mayak]] and [[Vesti FM]]. As in previous election campaigns, incumbent President [[Vladimir Putin]] refused to participate in the debates.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018_news/20180213/1514542724.html?inj=1|title=ЦИК получил уведомление об отказе штаба Путина от эфира для дебатов|date=20180213T1521+0300Z|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2018-02-28|language=ru}} Debates will also take place on regional TV channels and radio stations, which will be attended by representatives of all candidates, including Putin. Debates will take place from 26 February to 15 March.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/election2018/20180213/1514551192.html|title=Дебаты кандидатов в президенты завершатся 15 марта|date=20180213T1639+0300Z|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2018-02-28|language=ru}} Vladimir Zhirinovsky was the only candidate to attend the first debate, with the other three candidates sending representatives.{{Cite news|url=https://meduza.io/news/2018/02/26/v-rossii-proshli-pervye-predvybornye-debaty-iz-chetyreh-zayavlennyh-kandidatovyavilsya-odin|title=В России прошли первые предвыборные дебаты. Из четырех заявленных кандидатов явился один|work=Meduza|access-date=2018-02-26|language=ru-RU}} The second debate, which didn't actually involve any candidate-to-candidate discussion, was attended by six candidates and Boris Titov's representative.{{Cite news|url=https://meduza.io/feature/2018/02/28/eto-ne-debaty-eto-shkolnyy-urok|title=«Это не дебаты, это школьный урок»: На Первом канале прошли первые предвыборные дебаты. The '''2009 United States elections''' were held on Tuesday, November 3. During this [[off-year election]], the only seats up for election in the [[United States Congress]] were [[special election]]s held throughout the year. In total, only the seat representing [[New York's 23rd congressional district special election, 2009|New York's 23rd congressional district]] changed party hands, increasing the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]'s majority over the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] in the [[United States House of Representatives]], 258–177.

However, there were also several [[governor|gubernatorial]] races and [[State legislature (United States)|state legislative]] elections, and numerous [[Initiative|citizen initiative]]s, [[mayor]]al races in several major cities, and several types of local offices on the ballot.

== United States Congress ==
{{main|Special elections to the 111th United States Congress}}
In total, there were five [[Special elections to the 111th United States Congress#House of Representatives|special elections to the United States House of Representatives]] during 2009. The only election which changed party hands (from [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] to [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]]) was in [[New York's 23rd congressional district special election, 2009|New York's 23rd congressional district]].

Also, a primary election was held in [[Massachusetts]] on December 8, 2009, for the senate seat left open by the death of [[U.S. Senator]] [[Ted Kennedy]]; the [[United States Senate special election in Massachusetts, 2010|general special election]] for that later seat occurred on January 19, 2010.

== Governors ==
{{main|United States gubernatorial elections, 2009}}

[[New Jersey]] and [[Virginia]], along with the U.S. territory of the [[Northern Mariana Islands]], held gubernatorial elections in 2009. Both governorships in New Jersey and Virginia changed party hands from Democrat to Republican. Meanwhile, the local [[Covenant Party (Northern Mariana Islands)|Covenant Party]] maintained control of the governorship of the Marianas.

== State legislatures ==

Legislative elections were held for the [[New Jersey General Assembly]], the [[Virginia House of Delegates]] and the [[Northern Mariana Islands Commonwealth Legislature]].

== Municipalities ==
Cities, counties, school boards, special districts and others elect members in 2009.  Several large cities held mayoral elections in 2009, including: [[New York City mayoral election, 2009|New York City]], [[Boston mayoral election, 2009|Boston]], [[Los Angeles mayoral election, 2009|Los Angeles]], [[Houston mayoral election, 2009|Houston]], [[Minneapolis mayoral election, 2009|Minneapolis]], [[Seattle mayoral election, 2009|Seattle]], [[San Antonio mayoral election, 2009|San Antonio]], and [[Detroit mayoral election, 2009|Detroit]]. [[Memphis, Tennessee]] also had a special election to replace former mayor [[Willie Herenton]].

Some of these mayoral elections included the following:
* [[Albuquerque mayoral election, 2009|Albuquerque, New Mexico]] – [[Richard J. Berry]] (R) defeated Incumbent Mayor [[Martin Chavez]] (D).
* [[Albany mayoral election, 2009|Albany, New York]] – Incumbent Mayor [[Gerald Jennings]] (D) defeated Working Families Party candidate [[Corey Ellis]] and  [[Nathan LeBron]] (R).
* [[Anchorage mayoral election, 2009|Anchorage, Alaska]] – [[Dan Sullivan (Mayor of Anchorage)|Dan Sullivan]] (R) was elected mayor.
* [[Atlanta mayoral election, 2009|Atlanta, Georgia]] – Mayor [[Shirley Franklin]] (D) was term-limited. [[Kasim Reed]] (D) defeated [[Mary Norwood]] (D) in a runoff election.
* [[Austin mayoral election, 2009|Austin, Texas]] – Incumbent Mayor [[Will Wynn]] (D) was term-limited.
* [[Boston mayoral election, 2009|Boston, Massachusetts]] – Incumbent Mayor [[Thomas Menino]] (D) defeated [[Michael F. Flaherty]] (D).
* [[Buffalo mayoral election, 2009|Buffalo, New York]] – Incumbent Mayor [[Byron Brown]] (D) defeated Michael Kearns (D).
* [[Charlotte mayoral election, 2009|Charlotte, North Carolina]] – [[Anthony Foxx]] (D) defeated [[John Lassiter]] (R)
* [[Detroit mayoral election, 2009|Detroit, Michigan]] – Incumbent Mayor [[Dave Bing]] (D) defeated [[Tom Barrow]] (D)
* [[Henderson mayoral election, 2009|Henderson, Nevada]] – Incumbent Mayor [[James B. Gibson]] (D) was term-limited. He was succeeded by Democrat [[Andy Hafen]].
* [[Houston mayoral election, 2009|Houston, Texas]] – Incumbent Mayor [[Bill White (Texas politician)|Bill White]] (D) was term-limited. In a runoff election, [[Annise Parker]] (D) defeated [[Gene Locke]] (D).
* [[Jersey City mayoral election, 2009|Jersey City, New Jersey]]- Incumbent Mayor [[Jerramiah Healy]] (D) defeated Louis Manzo (D), L. Harvey Smith (D) and other minor candidates.
* [[Lancaster, Pennsylvania mayoral election, 2009|Lancaster, Pennsylvania]] – Incumbent Mayor [[Rick Gray (Pennsylvania politician)|Rick Gray]] (D) defeated [[Charlie Smithgall]] (R).
* [[Los Angeles mayoral election, 2009|Los Angeles, California]] – Incumbent Mayor [[Antonio Villaraigosa]] (D) defeated [[Walter Moore (politician)|Walter Moore]] (R).
* [[Manchester, New Hampshire mayoral election, 2009|Manchester, New Hampshire]] – [[Ted Gatsas]] (R) elected mayor succeeding mayor [[Frank Guinta]] (R).
* [[Minneapolis mayoral election, 2009|Minneapolis, Minnesota]] – Incumbent Mayor [[R.T. Rybak]] (DFL) was re-elected.
* [[New York City mayoral election, 2009|New York City, New York]] – Incumbent Mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]] (I) was re-elected.
* [[North Las Vegas mayoral election, 2009|North Las Vegas, Nevada]] – Incumbent Mayor [[Mike Montandon]] (R) was term-limited. He was succeeded by Republican [[Shari Buck]].
* [[Omaha mayoral election, 2009|Omaha, Nebraska]] – City councilman [[Jim Suttle]] was elected mayor after incumbent [[Mike Fahey]] declined to run for re-election.
* [[Pittsburgh mayoral election, 2009|Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] – Incumbent Mayor [[Luke Ravenstahl]] (D) was re-elected.
* [[Rochester mayoral election, 2009|Rochester, New York]] – Incumbent Mayor [[Robert Duffy (mayor)|Robert Duffy]] (D) was unopposed.  (The next year, he was elected [[Lieutenant Governor of New York]].)
* [[San Antonio mayoral election, 2009|San Antonio, Texas]] – Incumbent Mayor [[Phil Hardberger]] was term-limited. He was succeeded by Democrat [[Julian Castro]].
* [[Seattle mayoral election, 2009|Seattle, Washington]] – Incumbent Mayor [[Greg Nickels]] (D) defeated in the primary in August 2009. [[Mike McGinn]] (D) defeated [[Joe Mallahan]] (D).
* [[Saint Paul mayoral election, 2009|St. Paul, Minnesota]] – Incumbent Mayor [[Chris Coleman (politician)|Chris Coleman]] (DFL) was re-elected.
* [[Syracuse mayoral election, 2009|Syracuse, New York]] – Incumbent [[Matt Driscoll]] (D) was term limited. [[Stephanie Miner]] (D) defeated [[Steve Kimatian]] (R) and Conservative [[Otis Jennings]].
* [[Tulsa, Oklahoma mayoral election, 2009|Tulsa, Oklahoma]] – Mayor [[Kathy Taylor]] did not seek re-election. [[Dewey F. Bartlett, Jr.]] (R) defeated [[Tom Adelson]] (D).
